segment.source: 4826(S) Boot Configuration Data loaded.
segment.target: 4826(S) Boot Configuration Data loaded.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4826(S) Boot Configuration Data loaded.
segment.target: Describes security event 4826(S) Boot Configuration Data loaded.

segment.source: 4826(S): Boot Configuration Data loaded.
segment.target: 4826(S): Boot Configuration Data loaded.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time system starts and load current Boot Configuration Data (BCD) settings.
segment.target: This event generates every time system starts and load current Boot Configuration Data (BCD) settings.

segment.source: This event is always logged regardless of the "Audit Other Policy Change Events" sub-category setting.
segment.target: This event is always logged regardless of the "Audit Other Policy Change Events" sub-category setting.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2012, Windows 8.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2012, Windows 8.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that reported this event.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that reported this event.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Always “S-1-5-18” for this event.
segment.target: Always “S-1-5-18” for this event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that reported this event.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that reported this event.

segment.source: Always “-“ for this event.
segment.target: Always “-“ for this event.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Always “-“ for this event.
segment.target: Always “-“ for this event.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: General Settings:
segment.target: General Settings:

segment.source: Load Options Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.
segment.target: Load Options Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.

segment.source: Advanced Options Type = UnicodeString: shows whether Windows is configured for system boot to the legacy menu (F8 menu) on the next boot (Yes or No).
segment.target: Advanced Options Type = UnicodeString: shows whether Windows is configured for system boot to the legacy menu (F8 menu) on the next boot (Yes or No).

segment.source: You can enable advanced boot using “bcdedit /set onetimeadvancedoptions yes” command.
segment.target: You can enable advanced boot using “bcdedit /set onetimeadvancedoptions yes” command.

segment.source: Configuration Access Policy Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.
segment.target: Configuration Access Policy Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.

segment.source: System Event Logging Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.
segment.target: System Event Logging Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.

segment.source: Kernel Debugging Type = UnicodeString: shows whether Windows kernel debugging is enabled or not (Yes or No).
segment.target: Kernel Debugging Type = UnicodeString: shows whether Windows kernel debugging is enabled or not (Yes or No).

segment.source: You can enable kernel debugging using “bcdedit /debug on” command.
segment.target: You can enable kernel debugging using “bcdedit /debug on” command.

segment.source: VSM Launch Type Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.
segment.target: VSM Launch Type Type = UnicodeString: there is no information about this field in this document.

segment.source: Signature Settings:
segment.target: Signature Settings:

segment.source: Test Signing Type = UnicodeString: shows whether Windows test signing is enabled or not (Yes or No).
segment.target: Test Signing Type = UnicodeString: shows whether Windows test signing is enabled or not (Yes or No).

segment.source: You can disable test signing using “bcdedit /set testsigning off” command.
segment.target: You can disable test signing using “bcdedit /set testsigning off” command.

segment.source: Note This parameter controls whether Windows 8.1, Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, or Windows Vista will load any type of test-signed kernel-mode code.
segment.target: Note This parameter controls whether Windows 8.1, Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, or Windows Vista will load any type of test-signed kernel-mode code.

segment.source: This option is not set by default, which means test-signed kernel-mode drivers on 64-bit versions of Windows 8.1, Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, and Windows Vista will not load by default.
segment.target: This option is not set by default, which means test-signed kernel-mode drivers on 64-bit versions of Windows 8.1, Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, and Windows Vista will not load by default.

segment.source: After you run the BCDEdit command, restart the computer so that the change takes effect.
segment.target: After you run the BCDEdit command, restart the computer so that the change takes effect.

segment.source: For more information, see Introduction to Test-Signing.
segment.target: For more information, see Introduction to Test-Signing.

segment.source: Flight Signing Type = UnicodeString: shows whether Windows flight signing (which allows flight-signed code signing certificates) is enabled or not (Yes or No).
segment.target: Flight Signing Type = UnicodeString: shows whether Windows flight signing (which allows flight-signed code signing certificates) is enabled or not (Yes or No).

segment.source: You can disable flight signing using “bcdedit /set flightsigning off” command.
segment.target: You can disable flight signing using “bcdedit /set flightsigning off” command.

segment.source: Disable Integrity Checks Type = UnicodeString: shows whether Windows integrity check is disabled or not (Yes or No).
segment.target: Disable Integrity Checks Type = UnicodeString: shows whether Windows integrity check is disabled or not (Yes or No).

segment.source: You can disable integrity checks using “bcdedit /set nointegritychecks on” command.
segment.target: You can disable integrity checks using “bcdedit /set nointegritychecks on” command.

segment.source: HyperVisor Settings:
segment.target: HyperVisor Settings:

segment.source: HyperVisor Load Options Type = UnicodeString: shows hypervisor loadoptions.
segment.target: HyperVisor Load Options Type = UnicodeString: shows hypervisor loadoptions.

segment.source: See more information here: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/hardware/ff542202(v=vs.85).aspx.
segment.target: See more information here: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/hardware/ff542202(v=vs.85).aspx.

segment.source: HyperVisor Launch Type Type = UnicodeString: shows the hypervisor launch options (Off or Auto).
segment.target: HyperVisor Launch Type Type = UnicodeString: shows the hypervisor launch options (Off or Auto).

segment.source: If you are setting up a debugger to debug Hyper-V on a target computer, set this option to Auto on the target computer.
segment.target: If you are setting up a debugger to debug Hyper-V on a target computer, set this option to Auto on the target computer.

segment.source: For more information, see Attaching to a Target Computer Running Hyper-V.
segment.target: For more information, see Attaching to a Target Computer Running Hyper-V.

segment.source: Information about Hyper-V technology is available on Microsoft TechNet web site.
segment.target: Information about Hyper-V technology is available on Microsoft TechNet web site.

segment.source: HyperVisor Debugging Type = UnicodeString: shows whether the hypervisor debugger is enabled or not (Yes or No).
segment.target: HyperVisor Debugging Type = UnicodeString: shows whether the hypervisor debugger is enabled or not (Yes or No).

segment.source: For information about hypervisor debugging, see Attaching to a Target Computer Running Hyper-V.
segment.target: For information about hypervisor debugging, see Attaching to a Target Computer Running Hyper-V.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4826(S): Boot Configuration Data loaded.
segment.target: For 4826(S): Boot Configuration Data loaded.

segment.source: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
segment.target: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.

segment.source: Because this event is typically triggered by the SYSTEM account, we recommend that you report it whenever “SubjectSecurity ID” is not SYSTEM.
segment.target: Because this event is typically triggered by the SYSTEM account, we recommend that you report it whenever “SubjectSecurity ID” is not SYSTEM.

segment.source: If you have a standard or baseline for Boot Configuration Data settings defined, monitor this event and check whether the settings reported by the event are still the same as were defined in your standard or baseline.
segment.target: If you have a standard or baseline for Boot Configuration Data settings defined, monitor this event and check whether the settings reported by the event are still the same as were defined in your standard or baseline.
